{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3541611,"name":"Rishab Tirupathi","username":"rishabtirupathi","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/9d8465/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T18:15:45.878Z","cooked":"

In our robot, we have an intake where we take in coral. This intake has a funnel with 2 distance sensors (REV Distance Sensor V3). We planned to use our Teensy 4.0 microcontroller to “talk” to both distance sensors, since they both use the I2C protocol. Our Teensy was powered by its 5V and GND pins, which were connected to the analog lanes on the RoboRIO (where the 5V pins in the analog lanes are). The Teensy used 2 I2C buses, one for each distance sensor (because both sensors used the same address, we could not put both on the same I2C bus). Finally, the Teensy had a 3.3V pin and an additional GND pin to power both distance sensors.

This worked very well, the first time we tried it. However, on Saturday, our Teensy stopped working after running this code. It would not connect to the Arduino IDE or any tools at all, even if we pressed its “Program” button, and we could not detect a single sign of it.

Luckily, we had another Teensy 4.0. We tried to make it work in a similar configuration, but after a few hours of configuration and programming, it stopped working as well.

We thought that the first Teensy’s problems were caused by trying to power it from the 5V pin and the USB port at the same time, so we avoided that for the second Teensy, and yet it still broke.

Luckily, it turns out we do not need to use these Teensies, because we have PWM cliff sensors. We tried to avoid using them this year, because they were very bad at sensing Crescendo notes last year. However, we began to use them after the Teensies broke, and it turned out that they worked very well, and were very stable for Reefscape coral. Since we can simply connect these PWM sensors to our RoboRIO’s digital pins, we don’t need to use any microcontrollers anymore.

Nevertheless, I still want to know what may have happened with the Teensy 4.0 microcontrollers, that would cause them to both break in this way. Any explanations would be very helpful in making sure that we do not break any more microcontrollers in the future.

We have not had success working with the I2C port. So we do the same thing using this critter from Amazon.
[Amazon.com: HiLetgo 10pcs IR Infrared Obstacle Avoidance Sensor Module for Arduino Smart Car Robot 3-Wire Reflective Photoelectric for Arduino Smart Car Robot : Electronics](https://HiLetgo 10pcs IR Infrared Obstacle Avoidance Sensor Module)

Turn the POT down to the minimal range and feed the output into the FWD/REV limits on the motor controller.

I expect this will be a better experience for you.

If I’m not mistaken, the Teensy operates at 3.3 Volts. You may be able to power it by feeding it 5V (which will be regulated) but you will probably have issues running a 5V I2C signal from the Rio to the Teensy without using a 5V - 3.3V signal level converter.

Over-volting a data pin can work for awhile, until it doesn’t.

I think Veg pinned it. The Teensy 4.0 is 3.3V only; The Rio (IIRC) operates everything at 5V logic. The Teensy 3.2 is fully 5V tolerant, and a better choice for this environment.

Addendum: Just noticed that the Teensy 3.2 is discontinued, so… also not a great choice.

Which leaves you to either making the Teensy 4.0 5V tolerant by use of a buffer chip, and/or use a mux to re-address the Rev devices.

Adafruit has some good options for both cases with these two being nice examples.

adafruit.com

Adafruit TCA4307 Hot-Swap I2C Buffer with Stuck Bus Recovery

As we've been adding  STEMMA QT connectors to our breakouts and dev boards, folks have been really enjoying the simplicity and speed of plugging in I2C sensors and devices for quick ...

Price: $4.95 USD

adafruit.com

Adafruit PCA9548 8-Channel STEMMA QT / Qwiic I2C Multiplexer

You just found the perfect I2C sensor, available in a handy chainable Qwiic, or STEMMA QT package, and you want to wire up two or three or more of them to your microcontroller when ...

Price: $6.95 USD

House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T22:05:04.889Z","cooked":"

The Rio runs at 3.3V logic for the DIO, I2C and SPI lines. It’s just that the middle power pin outputs 5V (Although you can change that).

The PWM and Relay outputs are boosted to 5V logic, but they’re output only so not relevant.
